fun fact ... you can to a million experiments with a gyroscope to try and see it "move" due to earth's rotation, but you never will see that happen. It's because the earth isn't moving, it's flat. This one instrument proves 100% that the earth is stationary.
P.S. The Coriolis nonsense is just that ... nonsense. As a commercial pilot i can tell you that this fake force never affects aircraft in flight. It is never ever used in flight path calculations or heading adjustments. It's not real. They tell you that hurricanes, and bullets, and other objects "in the air" see this affect, but the reality is that not a single airplane or aircraft of any kind gets "pushed" off course when flying N/S. We fly a straight ass line only correcting for wind velocity, ZERO CORIOLIS CORRECTIONS. wake up!

Will deal with this in extreme long range shooting... At 1500 yards on you average 30 cal mag calibers
If you are shooting directly north or south you will have to dial in about 1.25 minutes (Minute of angle) of windage depending on the shot direction... That's about 18.75 inches of effect it has on the shot (exactly how much depends on time of flight for the bullet... At really long ranges bullet flight time can get pretty substantial and C effect has to be accounted for)...when shooting directly east or west at really long ranges we have to dial for C effect as well except on that axis its elevation that is adjusted for not windage. If you are shooting directly west then the target is moving towards the bullet so you won't dial as much hold over and if shooting due east the target is moving away from the bullet and you will dial in move elevation/hold over more... When really pushing the limit of long range shooting C effect is something you better understand well.

Very well explained sir with mathematical & physical annotations. At 11:00 there is no torque pushing it "this way". There would be torque "this way" only while making the wheel spin. Once it is spinning there is no torque "this way". Once the spinning wheel is released pivoted at one end then the only torque on it is due to downward gravity and direction of this torque would be inward to the screen plane to start with. This results in a small angular momentum component in the direction inward to the screen plane to start with which along with the wheel spin angular momentum component results in a preceding RESULTANT angular momentum and henceforth changes the direction of wheel plane and hence direction of gravity torque and hence the direction of the angular momentum component due to gravity and hence the direction of preceding RESULTANT angular momentum and in an ideal condition the wheel thus keeps preceding.
Since there is a continuous gravity torque there has to be a continuous angular acceleration & hence continuous angular velocity change. Here though the magnitude of angular velocity remains constant but as it keeps changing direction there is a continuous angular velocity change. Continuous acceleration need not always mean continuous magnitude change.

Minute 12  is true for paper airplanes (but who can push paper airplanes so far without them being affected by wind patterns), but it worries me since anything moving attached to the surface of Earth would not experience that after a push. Ocean water pushed by large scale wind bursts will follow a path of  inertial oscillations (near circles moving westwards, clockwise in the northern and anti-clockwise in the southern hemisphere), because of the Coriolis force. The explanation you give is wrong for any movement relative to Earth anywhere except for East-West paths along the equator.

The gyroscope will not process forever even on frictionless bearings or with a small motor that keeps the gyroscope spinning at a fixed speed. In fact if you install that bicycle wheel on a solid bar with a rotating bearing in the ceiling (so it always has to point 90deg horizontally) all processing stops. The proof for this is if you put a generator in that solid bar to extract energy from the procession (between where the bar is fixed to the roof and the rotation of the bar), you would be able to extract free energy forever, as it would be practically possible to have air bearings so low in friction and a motor so efficient at maintaining the gyroscope's speed, that you could extract more power than the energy to keep the gyroscope spinning at a constant speed.

It is in fact because gravity is allowed to act on the gyroscope that it processes, you can think of it like the outside tip of the gyroscope's axle being 'plugged in' to a fine-pitch screw thread, the faster the speed of the gyroscope's rotation, the finer the pitch and the 'weaker' / slower the procession (because it is 'falling down' slower). Eventually the axle of the gyroscope must be pointed straight down. Also as gyroscopes naturally slow, that is why the procession increases, because the 'corkscrew' gets a 'larger pitch / spacing'. The maximum amount of energy you could extract would be the same as if you just had a rope and generator attached to the outside axle and it fell down to its lowest point. At first I thought that energy was being 'harvested' from the gyroscope's rotation, but after a lot of research that is not theoretically possible (and doesn't fit any known data).

Phew, that took me ages to work it out because every single youtube video and online discussion gets this wrong, they all say the procession would occur forever. I would be fascinated to see a large gyroscope with a small stator (motor) in it to keep it at fixed RPM, and verify that this is correct, as the alternative is a free energy device and/or all a substantial branch of physics being wrong.

About the ball experiment.  Assuming no external forces ex:friction It could be said that a ball thats traveling in a horizontal direction that has a force acted upon it by a force in a perfect perpindicular direction can not ever have a velocity perfectly perpindicular to its original velocity,  no matter how hard you hit the ball.     But one could argue, "what about if you hit it at the speed of light?"    It would be impossible to do that fore in order to hit the ball and expect it to move you need an obect with mass.  And an object with mass can not go that fast, but would the resulting velocity be perpindicular to the original.     In theroy, no, but seeing how you can not graph the speed of the ball, for the ball experinces a stop in time relitive to the ball, so its not like it can record itself, and you can not record its Path of travel, fore you can not see it, (at this point does the ball even technicaly exist).     This is going nowhere, i think the balls velocity will have a linier p.o.t. nonperpindicular with the orignial velocity

It is claimed that the Earth and sky travel as one but then it is claimed that everything is traveling at independent speeds because of how spinning spheres have differing speeds over the entire area/volume/surface. Almost every part of a spinning sphere is traveling at different speeds. The spinning ball would explode into an expanding ever thinner disc shape. The sky would explode/expand into an ever expanding ever thinner sphere. The water wouldn’t be climbing into a ball but would instead spread out into an ever thinner spinning splat.

It is claimed that a gyro can resist the spin of the Earth but then it is claimed that a gyro could never be positioned perfectly upright and so would always begin to process. The procession due to imperfect vertical positioning would have a stronger effect than the procession due to a spinning ground. The variables wouldn’t allow for a precise enough measurement.

It’s imposiball for stuff on and in a spinning ball to all travel at the same speed. The supposed spinning Earth/Water/Sky ball simply couldn’t travel as one ball shape. If the Earth ball was completely solid then it would at least have a chance of being a spinning ball. The gasses would @#£&off into the available space. The explosion effect is exponential. The smallest movement away from the Earth ball makes the following movement away even easier. The clouds would need to some how gain speed to keep pace with the ground. Clouds actually travel speedier than the supposed spin of the Earth.

If “gravity” keeps the conflicting speeds all together as a ball then there wouldn’t be a Coriolis effect. It can’t be both ways. It’s plainly false to think that a spinning ball could have the same speed of travel throughout. Inertia/momentum is real. Bendy-space-time-via-all-matter is total fantasy.

Centrifugal force is often given credit where the second part of newtons first law. Which states that an object will remain in motion. A good example of this misconception is when you swing a bucket of water over your head and the water doesnt fall out. This is not due to centrifugal force, which many will say is the reason. This is in fact due to the motion of water being sideways. The force it is experiencing sideways is si great that it doesn't fall out, and this is the second part of newtons first law. It remains moving sideways.

Centrifugal force is very real. Consider a satellite in orbit. The Earth pulls on the satellite but the satellite via gravity pulls on the Earth radially as well.

Now which produces the greater force? The Earth or the satellite?

Answer is it's the same. If the Earth pulls 1000 Newtons on the satellite then the satellite pulls on the Earth 1000 Newtons.

Get a big satellite like the moon and the effect becomes obvious. The moon doesn't orbit around the center of the Earth. Rather they orbit each other around each other, the center of which is the barycenter.

So with the Earth and Moon, which force is centripetal? The answer is of course there is a radial force on both objects in the opposite direction of equal magnitude.

Btw, this all sums up to Newton's third law that requires an equal force in the opposite direction, always. No exceptions. All forces must sum to zero. There are no unopposed forces.

The relative size of the objects changes nothing. Also it doesn't matter if it's gravity, a string, a bowl, or whatever. It always works this way.

I ride a motorcycle and have always found it interesting that the gyroscopic effect of the spinning front wheel causes the bike to “fall over “ to the right when force is applied to the right side of the handlebars and the opposite is for the left side. This is counter to what we think should happen. You turn a car steering wheel to the left and the vehicle turns left. Not so on a motorcycle. This “counter steering “ is so subtle that when we ride a single track vehicle, bicycle or motorcycle at speed it is hard to tell what is going on. Even long time motorcyclists don’t realize that they are counter steering!
In an emergency this is bad. For you may hit what you are trying to avoid. I have a mantra: Push left turn left,push right turn right.

So how does a gyroscope assist a gimbal in a spacecraft to do its job?

So there is a different handling of the discus, the shotput, and the hammer throw.

An Olympic contender places the shot next to their neck with the hand in the direction 90° from the direction of the shoulder. Thus the hand is in a position to assist the shot to reach its destination as close to where the athlete's eyes see the target. It kind of takes into account the offset of the eyes from the target because the arm is a little offset from the exact 90° angle from the neck - to - shoulder line. In any case, the shotputter adjusts to make the shot make its mark. In a way, arrow shots follow this difference between eyes abdominal arrow on the string. Gun and rifle shooters taking thus into account call the difference between the gun and the kick "werble."

For discus and Hammer throw, the athlete must rotate to the left (counterclockwise from the top) to make their mark at a different angle than a shotputter. A hammer is released when the athlete is facing 90° from the target. The athlete relies on centripetal force to not only go perpendicular to the inward force created by the swinging athlete, but also the horizontal ballistic motion the swinging gives the hammer. For it is the force parallel to the ground that determines the distance.

A discus thrower has an advantage over the hammer thrower because the discus thrower, like the shotputter, can give vertical spin, accelerating the discus in the up direction due to its spin, which creates a further gyroscopic force. Any angular force can be determined by your right hand: curl your fingers in the direction of the spin, and the thumb shows the direction of the force.

To build anything that is solid and designed to last, or to put forward a proposition that can withstand the utmost scrutiny of logic and rationality, first there must be a solid foundation to be built upon.

Oxford English Dictionary (Abrv, OED)

Regardless of all assertions and all theories to the contrary, all things of the universal Cosmos are made up of two primary things, physical matter and energy,

Laws of Physics

There must be an input of energy for there to be an output of energy (Equally, without an input of energy, there cannot be an output of energy).

Given a continuous input of energy there must be a continuous output of energy.

Fact: The use of the two words input and output denotes that, particles of matter are intermediary vehicles between an energy input and an energy output.

Fact: It is the size and the density of particles/vehicles of matter that determines, the quantity of input energy that is needed, to fuel their motions and the quantity of radiant energy output force, that is needed to cause them to be attracted toward and to interact with each other, so that they can combine and grow.

OED: Force: A measurable influence that causes something to move.

Rational

11:20 you're technically incorrect. No force pushes it forward. The torque acts into the video (Towards the brick wall) and the angular momentum acts towards the axis (The string). Adding these together gets essentially a circle that is much like the one michael used to demonstrate velocity and centripital acceleration. The Linear momentum must point in the direction of the torque (which is always perpendicular to it) so it continually moves towards it, which happens to make the wheel go out.

To call it a force pushing it forward is disingenuous, it's more vector addition than a force.

This is what we should be paying our math and science teachers to do. I've just finished grad school, but I had a physics professor in undergraduate who I did not care for very much. Or so I thought. He had to teach the course a very particular way, with very particular subjects because of the curriculum and board decisions that were out of his control. Somehow or another, I ended up going to his house with some buddies to work on an little copper wire electric motor project we couldn't figure out. Well we ended up making electric bicycles, POWERFUL electric bicycles, and I was hooked. I couldn't stop thinking about magnets and coils, gear ratios, co-efficients of friction, battery material properties, you name it. My professor's house was full of trinkets and objects I had never seen or heard of in my life; so much knowledge, so much passion, so many interesting subjects, all stifled and silenced by administration. Sad world. I am not a physicist, I'm an environmental scientist, and I would go into teaching if it didnt mean I wouldnt be able to support myself

Centrifugal force definitely, provably, does exist. The "if allowed to continue" thing doesn't make any difference. You look at the force at a given instant, not what it would be under circumstances other than those under which you're observing the force. At a given instant, the centrifugal force, while the centripetal force is acting on whatever is orbiting, acts in the opposite direction to it. ALSO, you can measure centrifugal force in rotating frames of reference.

"Centrifical" is used, but not correct term.
"Centrifugal" force exists. It is not force on the rotating ball. It is force by the ball on the rope,
chain, wall, or on any other factor keeping the ball in circular path.
According to Law of Action and Reaction, Centrifugal force is
equal in intensity and opposite in direction to the Centripetal force.
~~~~~
From your explanation someone might think that Centrifugal force doesn't exist at all,
and that nothing would break apart a propeller or flywheel spinning too fast.
Some teachers already even ashame students that mention Centrifugal force.
Sadly, students mainly believe them.
~~~~~
To understand this thing would be enough to translate terms Centrifugal and Centripetal from Latin.
~~~~~
Speaking of "fictious" force, EVERY "force" is just mathematical representation.
Resultant of all real physical effects of the influence. Even simple force of your
finger on your palm is in reality sum of interactions between fields of every single
particle in your finger with fields of every single particle of your palm AND VICE VERSA.
(Law of Action and Reaction again.)
Forces between two complex objets are not given by nature, it is what we measure
and calculate for our practical use.
~~~~~
According to General Relativity Theory, even Gravitational force is not a force,
but innertial effect within curved space.. And that effect influences paths of
celestial and other bodies showing "real force" within the frame of reference.
Additionally, within local frame(s) Centrifugal and Coriolis forces are equaly real as Centripetal.

This is the first time I've ever heard that explained, about why angular momentum is conserved, by breaking it down to the additive properties of linear forces. And it suddenly makes so much more sense than it ever did for me! Before, I saw this kind of thing as an equation, (omega) = r x m x v. But now, I actually understand the physics behind it, not just the mathematical models.

Thank you so much for making this video! <3

I'm posting this for the purpose of the furtherance of education...! If you powered a gyroscope continuously it probably wouldn't remain in a stationary relative position whilst the Earth rotates, mainly because the forces involved are orders of magnitude smaller than the friction present in any gimbal or support mechanism you would necessarily have to have. Flat Earthers (bless their poor misguided souls!) often use this precise experiment to 'prove' that the Earth isn't spinning and therefore can't be a globe. But the science is 100% sound and using specialist bearings and suspension in a vacuum etc etc, you could certainly show this effect. There's serious doubt around the validity of Focault's gyroscope experiments by the way, because these techniques weren't available in the 1800s. Nevertheless, his pendulum (which he came up with later) shows the effect quite clearly.

Quick question about the traveling east/west and gaining/losing weight: like you said, this happens because of an object's inertia and scales with how quickly that object is moving relative to Earth's rotational reference frame. Well, photons have inertia (despite having no mass) and also are affected by gravity (again, despite having no mass). Plus, they move really really fast, actually as fast as absolutely possible. So, how does this influence our measurement of photons? If I look east, will everything be very slightly blueshifted than if I look west, and by how much? How fast does a person have to be rotating before we can actually spot this difference with our own eyes? How close to the consistency of applesauce would a human observer become if they attempted the previous situation?

The thing about gyroscopes that is most amazing to me is that they are exact physical representations of the abstract idea of a vector cross product in math. At his messenger lecture at Cornell in 1964, Richard P. Feynman discussed the character of physical law. His first lecture dealt with gravitation. He went with Newton's formulation for simplicities sake. The basic thesis though was that math is the character of physical law. There are six parts, IIRC, to the messenger lecture series. I believe it has also been transcribed into a book. I would strongly recommend anyone reading this to look up the messenger lectures and watch them. Feynman gives a great talk.

On a slightly metaphysical note, it seems that there is no underlying mechanism for the universe. Yes, it does obey physical laws, many of which we now know. However, their expression is strictly mathematical. An ultimate mechanism has not yet been discovered.

Vsauce, this is pretty accurate but when you talked about helicopters, the earth does move underneath and we do have to take it in to consideration when we fly instrument. We have a directional gyro inside the helicopter and we basically look at our compass and line up the DG with it, however we do need to adjust it about every 15 minutes. Two reasons; one is because of gyroscopic procession and bearing friction inside of the unit, and the other is to take in to account the Earth moving underneath of us making the direction our DG is facing, inaccurate. It's very slight, but it is there. Just a little nugget for ya.

Micheal, my name is Alvin Khoxayo, a senior at Windsor Locks High School in Connecticut. I understand that the planet we live on is spherical; however there is one explanation the flat Earth society routinely alludes to that I cannot counter myself. Many planes and ships navigating the globe utilize gyroscopes to produce an artificial horizon, a fixed plane constantly perpendicular to the gravity of Earth. Gyroscopes are used to determine this, because immediate gravity would not be effective while accelerating or decelerating. If a gyroscope truly resists external forces and remains fixed on its own plane, why do artificial horizons remain perpendicular to the gravity of Earth, which has an altering plane as you navigate across the globe?

Michael! as always, great video! a small contribution, you do can lose mass if you move around the earth, as you know, according to Einsteins famous equation, E = mc^2, so if you gain kinetic energy by moving faster to a higher orbit at a mountain for example you should have a small increase in mass by 1/2 m*∆v^2/c^2. Which is small, but anyway :). It would be interesting to see a video where you explain how can our weight change in different parts of the earth, locating yourself at the north pole, at the equator, and at a mountain close to the ecuator, as the city of La Paz for example at 4000 meters above the sea level. The diference in rotating speeds should be taken into account as well as the fact that the earth is not a perfect circle, meaning that the distance to the center of the earth varies depending on wether you're at the pole or at the ecuator and so does gravity : g ~ 1/r^2 by Newton's law. Maybe it would be interesting to determine where on Earth you can weight the most and where the less. Also how much would you weight if the Earth didn't spin.

14:22 The yellow curved line resembles an involute. Is it a true involute? Anyway, an involute curve is the basis for the profile shape of a gear-tooth that can be a universal form for gears of various numbers of gear teeth that can all mesh as pairs of gears while transferring rotary motion that's smooth and regular. This regular motion is called 'conjugate motion' that is constant, without gear-tooth induced positive or negative rotary accelerations! This allows geared transmissions to run at very high speeds without significant vibration. Involutes are very intriguing. To find out, visit here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Involute

All Matter has inertia, which is the effect mass has on how an object's motion accelerates or decelerates to applied forces. The rotational equivalent is the moment of inertia, which likewise determines how an object will accelerate and decelerate in rotational motion about any of the 3 arbitrarily determined orthogonal rotational axis's as it reacts to a torque.

Force = mass * acceleration (F = m*a)
Impulse = Force * time = mass * change in velocity = Change in Momentum (Impulse = F * t = m * (∆v ))

Note: Impulse equation basically means if you apply a force for a period of time, an object with mass, m, will experience a change in velocity.

Also

Angular Momentum = Moment of Inertia * Angular Velocity (L = I * ω)
Torque = Moment of Inertia * Angular Acceleration (τ = I * α)

Note: a similar impulse effect applies to rotation. (∆L = I * ∆ω = τ * t). Apply a torque for a period of time, and the angular velocity will change for a given geometry.

What I'm trying to accomplish is these similarities.

m is similar to I
F is similar to τ
a is simillar to α
A change in L is similar to m * ∆v = Impulse = Change in Momentum

See the similarities?

(F = m * a) is like (τ = I * α)
(Impluse = m * (∆v ) = F * t) is like (∆L = I * ∆ω = τ * t)

Now that you know all this, introduce a new concept. A spinning gyroscope is upright. You apply a force downward at it's perimeter. You now are encouraging an alteration of an active spinning axis which has angular momentum already, and its momentum is valued on 2 things. 1 is the moment of inertia that exists already, and the other is the angular velocity. These values combine, and you have a value for L, the angular momentum. It is this value of the angular momentum which resists changes in orientation of an actively rotating axis, and this is why gyroscopes resist tipping. This is why fast moving bicyles are easier to ride than slow moving bicycles. This is how tops work. This is why you can spin a ball on your finger tip. This is how frisbees, when thrown correctly, would be so stable as they soar through the air.

Yes, for an at-rest gyroscope, tilting it is simple. You apply a torque that would alter it's orientation, and it moves responsively.

Tilt a spinning gyroscope, however, and the story is different. When you apply a torque that would change the axis of rotation, active rotational momentum would have to be "redirected" around a new axis, so you find yourself fighting a form of inertia responsible for the gyroscopic properties you saw in the video. That rotational kinetic energy about the z-axis will now continue at a similar energy level about a different composite x-y-z axis in relation to the original z-axis, and the reason the spinning gyroscope resists motion is due to the fact that your excitation forces are literally applying to a system that already has a lot of established rotational energy in it, and you're acting to reorient its spinning conditions so that it's already high level of kinetic energy will be acting in a new plane or axis.

That's my take on it. If you agree with my logic, thumbs up so people can see. I hope I didn't confuse anybody.

Great video, but it misses out the full picture of centripetal motion. That is, you can have radial and tangential acceleration; the idea that all objects in circular motion move with constant radius and velocity isn't just wrong but contradicts the idea of a torque, since a torque can only exist when some force (hence some acceleration) is present. Michael doesn't explicitly say this, but when first describing a circle it is shown to us this way, and we are led to watch the whole video believing that the magnitude of the velocity of an object in circular motion is constant, even when it experiences a torque. It's a nitpick, but it can lead to some lazy physics.

Just to be clear, centrifugal force is actually a thing. It is just a matter of reference frames. If you are in a rotating frame of reference, the motion of objects needs to be explained using the fictitious force called "centrifugal force". The most common problem is that people forget that this force is only to be considered when using rotating frame of reference.

The gyroscopic effect is one reason why WWI pilots crashed in training or died in crashes during their first flights. The rotary engines (not a Wankel) of these biplanes changed the way the flight controls worked so pulling back on the stick would not cause the plane to go up but to the right or left. One reason training was needed to fly these planes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotary_engine

Good video, but the centrifugal force does exist in the non inertial reference frame of an object that is on another spinning object. Read Classical Mechanics by John R. Taylor, he shows the Coriolis force and the Centrifugal force as forces that act on something when it is rotating. But if you look at something that just left a rotating refrence frame, it will no longer experience the Coriolis and centrifugal forces.

It good to note that gravity itself does NOT produce a torque as you mentioned at ~9:17 since gravity at this scale puts equal force on all parts of the gyroscope. If gravity itself was applying the torque, then if you dropped the gyroscope from a few feet up, it would spin the same way it would on the table. However, that is not the case. If you dropped the gyroscope, it would fall straight downwards with a slight spin, different from the table-top trial. The torque is actually coming from the force the table - or, in this case, the cardboard beneath the gyroscope - applies upwards a distance from the center of mass. This is called the "normal" force. Just a neat thing to keep in mind about gravity!

At 3 minutes you start to talk about forces acting towards the centre of the circle. You talk about a rope and also about gravity. Later you mention that centrifugal force isn't real. All well and good, but I find a lot of people can't reconcile the thrown outwards effect of rope swinging with the definitely not thrown outwards effect of astronauts on the ISS - bearing in mind that in both cases there is only one single force acting. Here are some words about this that I wrote on another YouTube video by Physics Girl.....

This is interesting now. One guy below was talking about centrifuges. Imagine you're standing in a cradle that some giant is swinging around on a rope. Just like standing on the Earth you feel a floor beneath your feet and it feels like there's a force pulling you "down" (or outwards if you prefer) to that floor. This is why the notion of centrifugal force is so popular - because we've all experienced it. So why in the ISS aren't the astronauts thrown against the further wall of their space station? In both cases there is only one force acting, the rope wielded by the giant, or gravity in the ISS. And yet the astronauts drift weightlessly whilst you in your cradle are anything but. The difference between these two situations is as follows. The centripetal force applied to you by the rope is applied via the cradle floor. As you go up through your body, slice by slice, each slice applies and reacts the forces to the slices above and below, just like standing on the Earth. So it's like a pile of books on a table. The uppermost book only feels itself whereas the lowermost has to carry the force of all of them to the table. On the ISS however, the force of gravity isn't applied to an astronaut locally, through a floor or wall. It is applied to each and every atom and elementary particle of his body simultaneously.. So there is no stacking, slice upon slice. Every slice experiences the exact same force as every other. It's as though, instead of a single solitary rope, gravity has a vast number of ropes all pulling with the same acceleration on every particle of the astronaut's body, simultaneously.

Centrifugal force is very real in the rotating frame of reference of the person on the circular path...

Yeah, Newton's laws don't work in non-inertial reference frames but I'm just trying to point out that one shouldn't take one model as gospel.

The notion of a centrifugal force can be useful in some cases, albeit fictitious from the point of view of any reference frame not experiencing acceleration.

If you switch from one equally valid model to another, things can change -- even gravity is a fictitious force in relativistic terms (curvature of space-time geometry rather than a force per se).

[EDIT: Kind of sleep deprived at the moment of writing, so I don't take responsibility for the accuracy of the above at this time -- so take it with a grain of salt]

Talking about helicopters. The rotor is a spinning object which causes the same rotary precession. To tilt a helicopter, the pilot changes the angles of the rotor blades. If you want to tilt the helicopter forward, not the rear blades must increase their lift, but the blades on one side. In practice, the rotor blade angles are themselves rotated 90° relative to the control stick, such that pushing the stick forward will increase the blade angles on one side, instead of the rear.

I know, that at 13:48 the spinning direction becomes clear but that is 21 seconds late :D

The Eötvös effect explains something I read years ago about space travel: spacecraft taking off from the east coast of the USA, as the Space Shuttle used to do, require less fuel than spacecraft taking off in Europe.

Because you don't want to launch over populated areas, the best thing to do is try to take off over the ocean. From Florida, this means aiming east, and you get the benefit of the Eötvös effect - it acts like a tailwind. But from Europe, the ocean is to the west, and having to aim in that direction means you need to fight the Earth's spin, and that costs more fuel. It's kind of like the Earth flinging you ahead if you're going east, or holding onto a bungee cord if you're going west.

I also read that NASA maintained a few runways across the world in case they ever needed to abort a Space Shuttle launch while in progress. One of these was in Spain, and if it had ever been required, the Shuttle would have reached it twenty minutes after leaving Florida.

On a different note, thank you for coming up with an explanation of gyroscopic precession that's intuitive and will stick with me! A spinning helicopter blade is the same, push up or down on the rear or front and it goes left or right.
When in flight, a counterclockwise spinning blade is moving faster on the right side, and slower on the left. The wind speed on the right is added to, and subtracted from the left of the blade speed until a point where the wind speed=blade speed and the helicopter loses lift and noses down, slowing it but regaining lift; it has a maximum speed. Coaxial blades do not as both blades have an advancing blade at all times.

15:05, Michael: "you weigh less when traveling east."
Side note: Weight (N) = mass (kg) x gravity acceleration (m s-1)
15:15, Michael: "so if you want to quickly lose a bit over a lb, about half a kilo, get on that plane..."

You won't lose a lb when you're traveling east at the equator on a plane, because you won't lose mass while sitting on a plane, maybe a very insignificant amount of mass due to calorie consumption on breathing, digesting and etc.
But the lifting effect can reduce the gravity acceleration, resulting lower weight.

Due to axial precession, "earth's approximate 20,000 year wobble" (like the wobble of the spinning gyro in this video @ 9:05) - on December 21st, (3000 BC) autumn would have started (in the northern hemisphere).  Think of the earth's tilt in an autumn position from the sun.  And December 21st, (7000 AD) - spring will start / tilting in that position from the sun.  Basically earth's rotating tilt, it's axial precession, determines when the four seasons occur - not the man-made calendar.

The Coriolis Effect is a highly debated topic of discussion among long-range target shooters. The paper airplane analogy was interesting, since it uses an object which is traveling very slowly compared to a bullet. Mind you, we're talking about people trying to hit targets thousands of meters away; even a fast bullet takes several seconds to reach it's target at such extreme ranges. Most long shooters agree that, when shooting latitudinally, compensation for the Coriolis Effect is necessary, often in the form of several inches of adjustment.

If anyone is interested, you can do a quick Google search for an online Coriolis calculator. Most of them will be geared towards marksman applications, but it is still interesting to see how fast an object would need to travel for the Coriolis Effect becomes negligible, and how said effect changes with even small variable adjustments.

Anyway. just my two pennies' worth.

So I basically get it now. In order to understand the behaviour of spinning objects, all you have to do is determine and multiply the vectors at each progressive point in their movement.
I guess a more fundamental question is why forces and vectors add up the way they do, but that pertains to the realm of metaphysics.

Another thing I was thinking of was conservation of angular momentum. As I understand, it's just normal conservation of energy/momentum but with the added force of the tension (provided by the energy in the atomic/molecular bonds) changing the velocity of all the mass tethered to the axis of rotation.
Doesn't that tension take energy away from those bonds though? Don't all forces require some sort of energy expenditure?
Does that mean that a spinning iron ball, say, will eventually experience the disintegration of all its bonds if it keeps spinning indefinitely in frictionless space?

I could do the math but I never really had a concept of how a spinning object should be more likely to stay upright until I started playing Kerbal Space Program (also helped me understand orbits). If you assume that there is an imbalance (in a rocket) which would cause it to fall over, you can distribute this imbalance relatively evenly on the x and y plane. I saw this when the nose of a rocket was wobbling around in a circle, and it seemed like it was beginning to "tip" in every direction evenly. But just by distributing this tipping in the othe directions you can keep it relatively straight upright.

Hmm, so how much is earth's "raw" gravitational force if you remove the effect of inertia? In other words, if you were traveling west at the same rate as the rotation of the surface of the earth (thus removing the effect of inertia), how much would that impact your apparent weight?

In basic physics class you would calculate the force of 1 kilogram pushing on the earth like:
mass * acceleration = 1kg * 9.807 m/s² = 9,807N

But is this simple calculation assuming the inertia of an object at rest on the surface of earth, or just raw gravitational force?

If it doesn't include inertia then basic physics classes were sort of misleading (or rather incomplete) =P
On the other hand if it is inclusive then earth's gravity pull can't be 9,807m/s² like I've always been taught, which less likely.

Either way it would be interesting to know the answer :)

A little funfact for you guys:

- You can use the coriolis effect to determine where the wind is coming from when looking at a meteorological weathermap which shows atmospheric pressure. For example if an area has 1018 mbar, and the line shows where it is 1014 mbar. Draw a line with a 15 degrees inclide to the lowest atmospheric pressure and that is the direction the wind is coming from.
